diagrams.description: Hydrology encompasses multiple processes, measurements, and applications. The hydrological cycle components include precipitation (rainfall, snowfall, hail), interception (by vegetation canopy), evaporation (from water surfaces), transpiration (from plants), evapotranspiration (combined loss), infiltration (into soil), percolation (to groundwater), surface runoff (overland flow to streams), streamflow (channel flow), and groundwater flow (subsurface movement). Watershed characteristics feature drainage area, topography and slope, soil types and properties, land use and land cover, channel network geometry, and time of concentration. Surface water processes involve rainfall-runoff transformation, hydrograph analysis (rising limb, peak, recession), flood routing, baseflow separation, and snowmelt hydrology. Groundwater hydrology includes aquifer types (confined, unconfined, perched), Darcy's Law governing flow, hydraulic conductivity and transmissivity, storativity and specific yield, groundwater recharge mechanisms, and well hydraulics (drawdown, cone of depression). Hydrological models span empirical models (rational method, SCS curve number), conceptual models (unit hydrograph, Sacramento model), physically-based models (distributed models, finite element methods), and integrated models (SWAT, HEC-HMS, MIKE SHE, MODFLOW for groundwater). Measurement techniques include rain gauges (tipping bucket, weighing), stream gauging (rating curves, velocity-area method, acoustic Doppler), groundwater monitoring (piezometers, water level recorders), soil moisture sensors, weather stations (meteorological data), and remote sensing (satellite precipitation estimates, GRACE for groundwater, radar). Applications cover flood forecasting and warning, water supply assessment, drought monitoring and prediction, irrigation planning, hydropower design, contaminant transport modeling, ecosystem flow requirements, and climate change impact studies. Specialized fields include urban hydrology (stormwater management), ecohydrology (vegetation-water interactions), isotope hydrology (water source tracing), and cryosphere hydrology (snow and ice processes).
